title: DNA Staining Method Based on Formazan Precipitation Induced by Blue Light Exposure
procedures:
1. Preparing and Running the Gel
Prepare the non-denaturing 12% polyacrylamide gel gels using the Sodium Dodecyl Sulfate-Polyacrylamide Gel Electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) recipe found in Sambrook and Russell14 but using water instead of SDS.
	
To prepare 5 mL of resolving gel, use 1.7 mL of distilled water, 2 mL of acrylamide/bis acrylamide (30/0.8% w/v), 1.3 mL of 1.5 M Tris pH 8.8, 0.05 mL of 10% ammonium persulfate, and 0.002 mL of TEMED.
To prepare 2 mL of stacking gel use 1.5 mL of water, 0.33 mL of acrylamide/bis acrylamide (30/0.8% w/v), 0.25 mL of 1 M Tris pH 6.8, 0.02 mL of 10% ammonium persulfate, and 0.002 mL of TEMED. The dimensions of the gel are 7.3 cm x 8.2 cm x 0.075 cm (l x w x d).
Note: Use a 15 well comb of 0.75 mm thickness for the best sensitivity.
Add the appropriate amounts of 6x loading buffer and DNA sample to a 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube (e.g. use 1 µL of 6x loading buffer to 5 µL of DNA sample).
Place the gel in the vertical electrophoresis chamber.
	
Fill the chamber with 750 mL of 1x TAE buffer to run 2 gels. To prepare 1 L of 50x TAE, use 442 g of Tris base, 57.1 mL of glacial acetic acid, and 100 mL of 0.5 M EDTA pH 8. Add distilled water to a final volume of 1 L.
Load the samples in the gel. Run the gel at 100 V for 2 h.
Alternatively, prepare a 1x TAE agarose gel using the recipe found in Sambrook14.
	
Add 300 mL of 1x TAE to the horizontal electrophoresis chamber. Run the gel for 45 min at 100 V.
2. NBT-SG I Staining (Figure 1).
Acrylamide Gel Staining.

Prepare the solutions: 0.1% w/v NBT and 1.2x SG I.
Note: It is possible to use ethidium bromide, GelRed and SYBR Gold instead of SG I, but SG I had the best performance.
Pour 16.75 mL of 1.2x SYBR Green I solution into a container of appropriate size.
Note: We used the lid of a pipette tip box as a container, and these volumes are calculated to cover the gel using this container; its dimensions are 11.6 cm x 7.6 cm x 2.6 cm (l x w x d).
Place the gel in the solution. Add 3.25 mL of 0.1% w/v NBT solution to give 0.2 mM NBT and 1x (equivalent to 2.0 µM) SG I final concentrations.
Seal the container with plastic film, and completely wrap the container with aluminum foil to block any ambient light.
Note: The plastic film is used to prevent splashing and to avoid reaction of the aluminum foil with the staining solution.
Shake for 25 min on an orbital shaker at 60 rpm.
Remove aluminum and plastic cover. Expose to sunlight for 90 min maximum. Check every 5 min until the band of interest appears.
To use blue light, prepare a protoboard with 3 Light-Emitting Diodes (LED) and place the LEDs about 5 mm from the gel surface (check the staining continuously, as the time needed will depend on the intensity of the LED light source).
Agarose Gel Staining.
After preparing and running a 1% agarose gel as described in sections 1.4 (the dimensions are 1 cm x 6.2 cm x 7 cm; l x w x d), follow the same steps as in 2.1 with these modifications:

Pour 41.9 mL of 1.2x SG I solution into the lid of a pipette tip box; its dimensions are 11.6 cm x 7.6 cm x 2.6 cm (l x w x d). Add 8.1 mL of 0.1% NBT solution.
Seal the container with plastic film, and then completely wrap the container with aluminum foil to block any ambient light.
Shake for 1 h on an orbital shaker at 60 rpm.
3. Data Analysis.
NBT-SG I Calibration Curves.
Obtain gel images by scanning at 1200 dpi.
Open software for image analysis. Straighten the images using an image editor. Run an image densitometry.
Calculate the area under the curve. Prepare a graph of Signal/SignalMax versus DNA concentration.
4. DNA Recovery.
Prepare a 1% agarose gel in 1x TAE using the recipe found in Sambrook14.
Add 300 mL of 1x TAE to the horizontal electrophoresis chamber. Load 4 µL of 100 ng/µL pDJ10015 plasmid and DNA ladder following the scheme given in Figure 2. Run the gel for 1 h at 100 V.
Mark and weigh two 2 mL microcentrifuge tubes.
Cut the gel down the middle in order to have two identical halves. Each one should contain the ladder and the sample plasmid to compare the different staining techniques. A schematic representation is in Figure 2.
Stain one half with NBT-SG I as in step 2.
	
Cut out the plasmid band using a clean scalpel. Save the gel piece in one tube and weigh.
Stain the other part of the gel with SG I with 50 mL of 1x SG I solution and slowly shake (60 rpm) the gel for 1 h in darkness.
	
Place the gel on a transilluminator and expose for 2 min. Cut out the plasmid band using a clean scalpel.

Save the gel piece in the other tube and weigh.
Note: The protocol can be paused here while keeping the tubes at -20 °C.
Carry out plasmid extraction using a commercial gel extraction kit.
5. Plasmid Normalization.
In a 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube, add 10 µL of extracted plasmid and 60 µL of type I water. Mix and transfer to a 60 µL quartz cuvette or use 2 µL directly in a Nanodrop.

Dilute samples to 9.1 ng/µL.
Transform Escherichia coli (E. coli) competent cells (e.g. XL10 Gold) following the Inoue transformation procedure16 using 5 µL of dilute sample.
